articles.headline: December a Mixed Month for Auto Sales
articles.snippet: Ford’s sales declined 14 percent for the year, while both Chrysler and G.M. reported declines of more than 30 percent.
articles.abstract: Ford’s sales declined 14 percent for the year, while both Chrysler and G.M. reported declines of more than 30 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Automakers ended a miserable year with some less bad sales figures, though the Ford Motor Company was the only one of the three domestic companies to report higher numbers in December.

articles.headline: Google Shakes but Doesn’t Upend the Cellphone Market
articles.snippet: The Nexus One has cool features and clunky ones, but in the end, we should root for the success of the Google Store.
articles.abstract: The Nexus One has cool features and clunky ones, but in the end, we should root for the success of the Google Store.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google sure does love shaking up the system.

articles.headline: A Once-Defiant U.A.W. Local Now Focuses on G.M.’s Success
articles.snippet: U.A.W. Local 1112, long a thorn in General Motors’ side, is now working with the automaker to ensure its success and protect union members’ jobs.
articles.abstract: U.A.W. Local 1112, long a thorn in General Motors’ side, is now working with the automaker to ensure its success and protect union members’ jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LORDSTOWN, Ohio  For the better part of three decades, the car plant here was a seemingly endless source of trouble for General Motors.

articles.headline: Fed Missed This Bubble. Will It See a New One?
articles.snippet: A lack of explanation for why the Fed failed to recognize the economic bubble is the weak link in its push for power.
articles.abstract: A lack of explanation for why the Fed failed to recognize the economic bubble is the weak link in its push for power.
articles.lead_paragraph: If only we’d had more power, we could have kept the financial crisis from getting so bad.

articles.headline: Iran Shielding Its Nuclear Efforts in Maze of Tunnels
articles.snippet: The underground network complicates the West’s military calculus and obscures the scale of Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: The underground network complicates the West’s military calculus and obscures the scale of Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last September, when Iran’s uranium enrichment plant buried inside a mountain near the holy city of Qum was revealed, the episode cast light on a wider pattern: Over the past decade, Iran has quietly hidden an increasingly large part of its atomic complex in networks of tunnels and bunkers across the country.

articles.headline: U.S. Saw a Path to Qaeda Chiefs Before Bombing
articles.snippet: Before his suicide attack, a Jordanian militant was seen as the most promising Al Qaeda informant in years.
articles.abstract: Before his suicide attack, a Jordanian militant was seen as the most promising Al Qaeda informant in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Before detonating a suicide bomb in Afghanistan last week, a Jordanian militant was considered by American spy agencies to be the most promising informant in years about the whereabouts of Al Qaeda’s top leaders, including Ayman al-Zawahri, the terrorist group’s second-ranking operative.

articles.headline: Optimism Is Fresh Arrival in California Cul-de-Sac
articles.snippet: Among the families of Beth Court, a block in Moreno Valley, Calif., hit hard by the foreclosure crisis, optimism is taking hold.
articles.abstract: Among the families of Beth Court, a block in Moreno Valley, Calif., hit hard by the foreclosure crisis, optimism is taking hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORENO VALLEY, Calif.  Phil Winkler pays a neighborhood kid to mow his lawn, that small-bore transaction of the American suburb, where adults are generally busy and teenagers offer a price that’s right. But for Mr. Winkler, the relinquishing of his mower was something remarkable.

articles.headline: Television Begins a Push Into the 3rd Dimension
articles.snippet: Cable programmers are rushing to create new channels for 3-D sets that manufacturers are unveiling.
articles.abstract: Cable programmers are rushing to create new channels for 3-D sets that manufacturers are unveiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ralph Kramden can finally buy a television.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Asian Computer Makers Move Into Riskier Ventures
articles.snippet: Companies that once built devices to Silicon Valley’s specifications are now investing in start-ups so they can compete with their former customers.
articles.abstract: Companies that once built devices to Silicon Valley’s specifications are now investing in start-ups so they can compete with their former customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  For years, the process remained relatively static: PC makers like Hewlett-Packard and Apple, with well-staffed research labs and design departments, would dream up their next product and then hire a Chinese or Taiwanese fabricator to manufacture the largest number of units at the lowest possible cost.
